location: Modern-day Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, and northern Iran

causes: Russian annexation of Georgia in 1801, a former Persian vassal state.
Persian Shah Fath Ali's attempts to reclaim lost territories.
events_leading_up_to_war: Russia’s growing influence in the Caucasus, culminating in Georgia's annexation.
Persian military campaigns to reassert dominance in the region.
Failed negotiations between Russia and Persia over territorial control.

result.general: Russian victory, territorial expansion in the Caucasus.

treaties.name: Treaty of Gulistan
terms: Persia ceded most of modern-day Azerbaijan, Daghestan, and eastern Georgia to Russia.
Persia lost access to the Caspian Sea's western coast.
Russia gained dominance in the Caucasus, paving the way for future conflicts.

territorial_changes: Russia gained large portions of the Caucasus.
Persia's influence over the region drastically weakened.

allies: Local Caucasian tribes loyal to Persia

Russia.tactics: Fortified positions, superior artillery, use of disciplined European-style warfare

Persia.tactics: Cavalry raids, reliance on tribal levies, siege warfare

major_battles.name: Siege of Ganja
major_battles.description: Russian forces led by General Pavel Tsitsianov stormed the Persian-held fortress of Ganja, massacring its defenders and civilians.
major_battles.outcome: Russian victory; solidified Russian control over eastern Georgia.

major_battles.name: Battle of Aslanduz
major_battles.description: Decisive battle where Russian General Kotlyarevsky's small force defeated a much larger Persian army led by Abbas Mirza.
major_battles.outcome: Russian victory; broke Persian military resistance.

major_battles.name: Battle of Lankaran
major_battles.description: Final battle of the war; Russians stormed the Persian fortress of Lankaran with heavy casualties on both sides.
major_battles.outcome: Russian victory; led directly to the Treaty of Gulistan.

texts.name: Persian Court Chronicles
texts.author: Fath Ali Shah's Court Historians
texts.details: Accounts of the war from the Persian perspective, emphasizing Russian aggression.

texts.name: Russian Military Dispatches
texts.author: Russian General Staff
texts.details: Detailed reports on campaigns, strategies, and battles.

archaeological_evidence.description: Ruins of Persian and Russian forts in the Caucasus, such as the remains of Ganja and Lankaran fortresses.
Persian swords, Russian muskets, and artillery remnants found in battle sites.

political: Marked the beginning of Russian dominance in the Caucasus.
Weakened Qajar Persia, leading to further Russian interventions.
long_term_effects: Set the stage for another Russo-Persian War (1826–1828).
